Die ersten Familien sind sicher in Werne angekommen! Die Familie links auf dem Bild hat bis Mittwoch nicht geglaubt, dass es zu einem Krieg kommen könnte. Der Familienvater war 500 km vom rest der Familie getrennt, am arbeiten.  Durch drängen von Freunden fuhr er dennoch vorsichtshalber zurück zum Rest seiner Familie, die 100 km von Kiew leben. Der Krieg traf sie trotzdem aus dem Nichts. Der große Sohn erzählte, sie konnten die ganze Nacht nicht schlafen wegen der Raketen und der Einschläge. Es wäre surreal gewesen, wie ein Horrorfilm oder Albtraum. Dann bekam er während des Gesprächs eine SMS von seinem Freund, der schrieb, dass alles soweit "okay" wäre. Sie wären ruhig. Aber es würden am hellichten Tag offene Kämpfe auf den Straßen stattfinden. Die kleineren Kinder (2 Frauen mit je zwei Kindern sind auch noch gekommen) haben zusammen gespielt. Es geht ihnen soweit ganz gut, aber sie möchten nach Hause nach Kyjiv und sind traurig,weil das nicht geht, sagt Margarita gerade. 

So sieht's aus.

The civilized world is watching with horror as Putin is destroying Ukraine for no other reason than his own vicious greed. As so many of us watch, feeling helpless, I would like to draw your attention to a good friend of mine whose family is caught in the struggle. 
Maksym Deomin @maksym_deomin is a friend of mine who lives with his wonderful wife, Anzhela & their children in Kyiv - except now they've been forced to flee their home for their own safety & are together facing some very frightening and uncertain times.

Like Maksym, I’ve built & run my own business & provide for my family doing so…I look at my friend, who does what I do - someone whose career is one of an artist & musical performer and teacher - a drummer who shares the joy of learning and making music with others - and I’m trying to wrap my head around what I would do & how I would survive in his shoes. It’s almost impossible to imagine & yet it is now his reality. 
I know I can’t help everyone suffering through this madness but I can help my friend & his beautiful family. If you can spare anything to donate yourself to help him, too, there is a secure link - 

https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/MaksymDeomin

- that I have been able to use successfully to send support.
 
Even if it’s only $1.00, I imagine if all of the friends I have on my combined social media pages could send just that - it would go a long way to help one family whose lives & dreams are are total disarray due to the vile actions of Vladimir Putin. 
Thank you for taking the time to read this & helping if you can. Peace & Love,
David Stanoch

Awesome Days in Kiev and Lviv

In 2017 when I was giving my master classes in Kiev and Lviv. My family is from Ukraine. These two cities are incredibly beautiful, as are the people who live there. I never felt so welcomed anywhere in my life as I was there. 

When I arrived, my host and close friend @maksym_deomin took me to the Bobi Yar Holocaust Memorial that was just bombed last week. During our time off Maksym and the other drummers showed me the Gates of Kiev, as well as beautifully historic churches. And the food..great borscht and great Votka!! 

The friends I made there are friends for life, as I continue to teach them via Zoom each week. I also teach drummers from Russia (all students of Maksym) in these Zoom classes, and they are wonderful people as well (drummers are drummers wherever you go). 

I hope to go back there sometime soon. The people I met there are tough and resilient, as well as kind and generous.

Um dies besser gewährleisten zu können, haben wir uns entschieden uns neu aufzustellen, um dann noch einmal besser vorbereitet zurückzukehren. As soon as word came in about the murders and destruction in Borodianka, URO’s (Ukraine Resistance Organisation) founders Aleksey Brynzak and Ireesha Blohina packed their suv full of supplies and went there. Even with the reports about Bucha, Mariupol and so many other Ukrainian towns and cities that have been destroyed, what they found in Borodianka was that much worse. A bucolic, peaceful, totally defenseless suburb of Kyiv, Borodianka looked like the site of an epic battle — except there was no battle here. Just the Russian invaders doing what they do: terrorize, torture, rape, pillage, decimate…

Apparently the Russians used Borodianka as a respite from the battles they were waging against the Ukrainian military nearby in Irpin, Bucha, etc. They used it and the residents there as some twisted version of a playground, forcing residents to cook for them — and much, much worse. And then tortured and killed them. There is no body count yet because this went on for over a month there. Mass graves, bodies crushed in the rubble of toppled buildings… a senseless, murderous, savage massacre of an innocent community.

It took Aleksey and Ireesha 4 hours to get to Borodianka. Normally it would take 30 minutes, but the highways and roads have been destroyed, forcing them to go off road through forests, fields, etc. Dangers all around them including mines, bombs that didn’t detonate and the possibility of straggler Russian soldiers and snipers.

The survivors here have nothing — no food, water, power, medical support (most have no hearing because of the incessant bombing).

Borodianka was not a strategic military target whatsoever. It fell into the other category of Russian offensives: civilian terrorism.

URO is working tirelessly converting funding to direct, on-the-ground support for the military (providing flak jackets, uniforms and other items to soldiers) and humanitarian support for the victims.

I know this because I worked with them while I was in Kyiv.
